title: The Confrontation at the Cottage
narrative_instruction: Open the novel in third person limited, past tense, focusing on Red’s perceptions as she and Elias confront 'Grandmother' (Lucien in disguise). Since this is the reader’s first encounter with the characters, introduce Red, Elias, and Lucien with clear, vivid physical and emotional details. Subtly imply their connections through dialogue and body language, but avoid referencing previous shared experiences. Present Lucien’s confession and Grandmother’s secret as dramatic revelations, planting intrigue for backstory to be explored in later chapters.
transition_hint: Begin in medias res, with sensory details (smells, tension in the air) drawing the reader directly into the confrontation. End the chapter with Red reeling from Lucien’s confession, gazing at a letter she pulls from her basket—this letter acts as a segue to the next chapter.

title: Red Receives a Mysterious Letter
narrative_instruction: Maintain third person limited, past tense, focusing on Red. This chapter serves as a flashback, providing the context for Red’s journey and the mysterious letter from Grandmother. Show Red’s relationship with her mother and her resolve to uncover family secrets. Build curiosity about the events that lead to the confrontation in Chapter 5.
transition_hint: Transition from the previous chapter by having Red’s attention linger on the letter she found in her basket, triggering a memory—shift smoothly into the flashback as she recalls receiving the letter.

title: Wolf's Interception and Deception
narrative_instruction: Continue third person limited, past tense, switching focus as needed between Red and Elias to maintain tension. Introduce Lucien as a mysterious stranger, ensuring his interactions feel fresh and unfamiliar to Red and Elias. Highlight Red’s wariness and Elias’s protective instincts. Avoid any forward references to the confrontation already shown in Chapter 5.
transition_hint: After the flashback in Chapter 1, transition forward with Red starting her journey in the forest, encountering Elias. End with their decision to travel together, naturally leading to Lucien’s interception.

title: Grandmother’s Disappearance
narrative_instruction: Maintain third person limited, past tense, focusing on Lucien’s increasing desperation and Red and Elias’s growing unease. Emphasize the strangeness of the empty cottage and Red’s suspicion. Keep allusions to the earlier confrontation ambiguous, keeping the timeline consistent.
transition_hint: Direct continuation—have the prior chapter end with Lucien hurrying ahead; open this chapter with his arrival at the cottage, followed by Red and Elias’s arrival.

title: Red Encounters the Woodsman
narrative_instruction: Continue using third person limited, past tense, focusing on Red’s impressions as she meets Elias for the first time. Develop their dynamic with initial wariness giving way to mutual attraction. Ensure their interactions feel like genuine first encounters, matching the timeline where they have not yet experienced the events of Chapters 3-5 together.
transition_hint: Insert this chapter as a flashback or interpolation after the tension at the cottage—perhaps triggered by an object or a remark reminding Red of when she first met Elias.

title: Red’s Choice and Grandmother’s Return
narrative_instruction: Maintain third person limited, past tense, focusing on Red’s emotional state as she faces Grandmother’s manipulations and makes her own choice. Ensure all characters’ relationships reflect the accumulated experiences of previous chapters, with Red’s growth and agency at the forefront. Bring closure to the romantic and familial tensions.
transition_hint: Direct continuation—open with Grandmother’s return, picking up immediately after the events and emotional beats of the confrontation and revelations.
